paragraphs.original: The fund managers, who are called "general partners," get about 2% of the fund annually as a management fee, plus about 20% of the fund's gains.There is a very sharp dropoff in performance among VC firms, because in the VC business both success and failure are self-perpetuating.
paragraphs.translated: 基金的管理者，被称为“普通合伙人”，每年可以从基金中获得大约2%的管理费，外加基金收益的大约20%。在风险投资公司中，业绩表现存在非常显著的分化，因为在这个行业里，成功和失败都是自我延续的。

paragraphs.original: When an investment scores spectacularly, as Google did for Kleiner and Sequoia, it generates a lot of good publicity for the VCs. And many founders prefer to take money from successful VC firms, because of the legitimacy it confers.
paragraphs.translated: 当一项投资表现得极为出色，比如谷歌对凯鹏华盈和红杉资本而言，这会为风险投资公司带来大量的正面宣传。许多创始人更愿意从成功的风险投资公司那里获得资金，因为这会赋予他们合法性。

paragraphs.original: Hence a vicious (for the losers) cycle: VC firms that have been doing badly will only get the deals the bigger fish have rejected, causing them to continue to do badly.As a result, of the thousand or so VC funds in the US now, only about 50 are likely to make money, and it is very hard for a new fund to break into this group.In a sense, the lower-tier VC firms are a bargain for founders.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，形成了一种对失败者来说的恶性循环：表现不佳的风险投资公司将只能获得大型投资机构拒绝的项目，这导致它们继续表现不佳。结果，在美国现有的大约一千家风险投资基金中，只有大约50家有望盈利，而新基金要想进入这个群体非常困难。从某种意义上说，较低层级的风险投资公司对创始人来说是一个便宜的选择。

paragraphs.original: They may not be quite as smart or as well connected as the big-name firms, but they are much hungrier for deals. This means you should be able to get better terms from them.Better how? The most obvious is valuation: they'll take less of your company.
paragraphs.translated: 他们可能不像那些大牌公司那样聪明或人脉广泛，但他们对交易的渴望程度要高得多。这意味着你应该能够从他们那里获得更优惠的条件。更优惠在哪里？最明显的是估值：他们会接受你公司更少的股份。

paragraphs.original: But as well as money, there's power. I think founders will increasingly be able to stay on as CEO, and on terms that will make it fairly hard to fire them later.The most dramatic change, I predict, is that VCs will allow founders to cash out partially by selling some of their stock direct to the VC firm.
paragraphs.translated: 但除了金钱，还有权力。我认为创始人将越来越能够继续担任首席执行官，并且在一些使其日后被解雇相当困难的条件下。我预测最显著的变化是，风险投资公司将允许创始人通过直接向风投公司出售部分股票来实现部分套现。

paragraphs.original: VCs have traditionally resisted letting founders get anything before the ultimate "liquidity event." But they're also desperate for deals. And since I know from my own experience that the rule against buying stock from founders is a stupid one, this is a natural place for things to give as venture funding becomes more and more a seller's market.The disadvantage of taking money from less known firms is that people will assume, correctly or not, that you were turned down by the more exalted ones.
paragraphs.translated: 风险投资家们传统上一直抵制让创始人在最终的“流动性事件”之前获得任何收益。但他们现在也迫切需要交易。由于我从自己的经验中知道，禁止从创始人手中购买股票的规定是一个愚蠢的规定，因此随着风投资金越来越成为一个卖方市场，这里自然成为了可以妥协的地方。从不太知名的公司那里拿钱的缺点是，人们会认为（无论正确与否）你被更有声望的公司拒绝了。

paragraphs.original: But, like where you went to college, the name of your VC stops mattering once you have some performance to measure. So the more confident you are, the less you need a brand-name VC. We funded Viaweb entirely with angel money; it never occurred to us that the backing of a well known VC firm would make us seem more impressive.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，就像你上哪所大学一样，一旦你有了可以衡量的业绩，风投公司的名字就不再重要了。所以，你越自信，就越不需要有名气的风投公司。我们完全是用天使资金创办了Viaweb；我们从未想过，有知名风投公司的支持会让我们显得更出色。

paragraphs.original: [5]Another danger of less known firms is that, like angels, they have less reputation to protect. I suspect it's the lower-tier firms that are responsible for most of the tricks that have given VCs such a bad reputation among hackers.
paragraphs.translated: [5]另一个不知名公司带来的危险是，像天使投资人一样，它们有较少的声誉需要维护。我怀疑是这些较低层级的公司造成了大多数的不当行为，这些行为使得风险投资家在黑客中声誉不佳。

paragraphs.original: They are doubly hosed: the general partners themselves are less able, and yet they have harder problems to solve, because the top VCs skim off all the best deals, leaving the lower-tier firms exactly the startups that are likely to blow up.For example, lower-tier firms are much more likely to pretend to want to do a deal with you just to lock you up while they decide if they really want to.
paragraphs.translated: 他们处于双重困境：普通合伙人自身能力较弱，但面临的问题却更加棘手，因为顶级风投已经把最好的交易都挑走了，留给二三线风投的恰恰是那些可能失败的初创企业。例如，二三线风投更可能假装想与你达成交易，只是为了在决定是否真正想要投资之前锁定你。

paragraphs.original: One experienced CFO said: The better ones usually will not give a term sheet unless they really want to do a deal. The second or third tier firms have a much higher break rate—it could be as high as 50%.
paragraphs.translated: 一位资深的首席财务官说：优秀的公司通常只有在真正想做成交易时才会发出条款书。而二流或三流的公司则有更高的破裂率，可能高达50%。

paragraphs.original: It's obvious why: the lower-tier firms' biggest fear, when chance throws them a bone, is that one of the big dogs will notice and take it away. The big dogs don't have to worry about that.Falling victim to this trick could really hurt you.
paragraphs.translated: 原因很明显：低层公司最担心的是，当机会偶然降临，大公司会注意到并夺走这个机会。大公司则不必担心这一点。落入这个陷阱可能会对你造成严重伤害。

paragraphs.original: As one VC told me: If you were talking to four VCs, told three of them that you accepted a term sheet, and then have to call them back to tell them you were just kidding, you are absolutely damaged goods.
paragraphs.translated: 正如一位风险投资家告诉我的：如果你同时与四位风险投资家交谈，告诉其中三位你已经接受了条款书，然后又不得不打电话回去告诉他们你只是开玩笑，那你绝对会被视为不可靠的。

paragraphs.original: Here's a partial solution: when a VC offers you a term sheet, ask how many of their last 10 term sheets turned into deals. This will at least force them to lie outright if they want to mislead you.Not all the people who work at VC firms are partners.
paragraphs.translated: 这里有一个部分解决方案：当风险投资（VC）向你提供条款清单时，询问他们过去10份条款清单中有多少最终变成了交易。这至少会迫使他们如果想误导你的话必须直接撒谎。并不是所有在风险投资公司工作的人都是合伙人。

paragraphs.original: Most firms also have a handful of junior employees called something like associates or analysts. If you get a call from a VC firm, go to their web site and check whether the person you talked to is a partner.
paragraphs.translated: 大多数公司还有一小批初级员工，通常被称为助理或分析师。如果你接到风投公司的电话，可以去他们的网站查看你交谈的人是否是合伙人。

paragraphs.original: Odds are it will be a junior person; they scour the web looking for startups their bosses could invest in. The junior people will tend to seem very positive about your company. They're not pretending; they want to believe you're a hot prospect, because it would be a huge coup for them if their firm invested in a company they discovered.
paragraphs.translated: 很可能是个资历较浅的人；他们会在网上搜索他们的老板可以投资的初创公司。这些资历较浅的人通常会对你的公司表现出非常积极的态度。他们并不是在装样子；他们希望你是潜力股，因为如果他们发现的公司能被他们的公司投资，那对他们来说将是一个巨大的胜利。

paragraphs.original: Don't be misled by this optimism. It's the partners who decide, and they view things with a colder eye.Because VCs invest large amounts, the money comes with more restrictions. Most only come into effect if the company gets into trouble.
paragraphs.translated: 不要被这种乐观情绪所误导。决定权在于合伙人，他们看待问题时更加冷静。由于风投投入的资金数额巨大，这些资金通常会附带更多的限制条件。大多数限制只有在公司出现问题时才会生效。

paragraphs.original: For example, VCs generally write it into the deal that in any sale, they get their investment back first. So if the company gets sold at a low price, the founders could get nothing. Some VCs now require that in any sale they get 4x their investment back before the common stock holders (that is, you) get anything, but this is an abuse that should be resisted.Another difference with large investments is that the founders are usually required to accept "vesting"—to surrender their stock and earn it back over the next 4-5 years.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，风险投资公司通常会在交易中规定，在任何出售情况下，他们首先要拿回自己的投资。因此，如果公司以低价出售，创始人可能什么都得不到。现在有些风险投资公司要求在任何出售中，他们要先拿回四倍于其投资额的资金，然后再让普通股股东（即你）获得任何收益，但这种做法是一种滥用，应该予以抵制。大额投资的另一个不同之处在于，通常要求创始人接受“期权归属”——即放弃他们现有的股票，并在未来4-5年内重新赚回这些股票。

paragraphs.original: VCs don't want to invest millions in a company the founders could just walk away from. Financially, vesting has little effect, but in some situations it could mean founders will have less power. If VCs got de facto control of the company and fired one of the founders, he'd lose any unvested stock unless there was specific protection against this.
paragraphs.translated: 风投不想投资数百万在一家创始人可以随意离开的公司。从财务角度来看，股权 vesting（归属）影响不大，但在某些情况下，它可能意味着创始人将拥有更少的权力。如果风投实际上控制了公司并解雇了一位创始人，除非有特定的保护措施，否则该创始人将失去任何未归属的股票。

paragraphs.original: So vesting would in that situation force founders to toe the line.The most noticeable change when a startup takes serious funding is that the founders will no longer have complete control. Ten years ago VCs used to insist that founders step down as CEO and hand the job over to a business guy they supplied.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，在那种情况下，股权分期授予会迫使创始人遵守规则。初创公司接受大额融资后最明显的变化是，创始人将不再拥有完全的控制权。十年前，风投公司通常坚持要求创始人卸任首席执行官，把职位交给他们推荐的商业人士。

paragraphs.original: This is less the rule now, partly because the disasters of the Bubble showed that generic business guys don't make such great CEOs.But while founders will increasingly be able to stay on as CEO, they'll have to cede some power, because the board of directors will become more powerful.
paragraphs.translated: 这已经不那么普遍了，部分原因是泡沫的灾难表明，一般的商业人士并不一定能成为出色的CEO。但尽管创始人越来越有可能继续担任CEO，他们将不得不让出一些权力，因为董事会的权力将会增强。

paragraphs.original: In the seed stage, the board is generally a formality; if you want to talk to the other board members, you just yell into the next room. This stops with VC-scale money. In a typical VC funding deal, the board of directors might be composed of two VCs, two founders, and one outside person acceptable to both.
paragraphs.translated: 在种子阶段，董事会通常只是一个形式；如果你想和其他董事会成员交谈，只需要大声喊到隔壁房间就行。这种情况随着风险投资规模的资金而改变。在典型的风投融资交易中，董事会可能由两位风险投资家、两位创始人和一位双方都认可的外部人士组成。

paragraphs.original: The board will have ultimate power, which means the founders now have to convince instead of commanding.This is not as bad as it sounds, however. Bill Gates is in the same position; he doesn't have majority control of Microsoft; in principle he also has to convince instead of commanding.
paragraphs.translated: 董事会将拥有最终决定权，这意味着创始人现在必须说服而不是命令。然而，这并不像听起来那么糟糕。比尔·盖茨也处于同样的位置；他没有微软的多数控制权；原则上，他也必须说服而不是命令。

paragraphs.original: And yet he seems pretty commanding, doesn't he? As long as things are going smoothly, boards don't interfere much. The danger comes when there's a bump in the road, as happened to Steve Jobs at Apple.Like angels, VCs prefer to invest in deals that come to them through people they know.
paragraphs.translated: 然而，他看起来还是很强势的，不是吗？只要一切顺利，董事会不会过多干涉。危险在于当遇到挫折时，就像史蒂夫·乔布斯在苹果公司遇到的情况一样。像天使投资者一样，风险投资家也倾向于投资通过他们认识的人介绍的项目。

paragraphs.original: So while nearly all VC funds have some address you can send your business plan to, VCs privately admit the chance of getting funding by this route is near zero. One recently told me that he did not know a single startup that got funded this way.I suspect VCs accept business plans "over the transom" more as a way to keep tabs on industry trends than as a source of deals.
paragraphs.translated: 所以，尽管几乎所有的风险投资基金都有一个你可以发送商业计划的地址，但风险投资家私下里承认，通过这种方式获得资金的机会几乎为零。最近有一位风险投资家告诉我，他不认识任何一个通过这种方式获得资金的初创公司。我怀疑风险投资家接受“越墙而来”的商业计划更多的是为了了解行业趋势，而不是作为投资机会的来源。

paragraphs.original: In fact, I would strongly advise against mailing your business plan randomly to VCs, because they treat this as evidence of laziness. Do the extra work of getting personal introductions. As one VC put it: I'm not hard to find.
paragraphs.translated: 事实上，我强烈建议不要随意将你的商业计划书寄给风险投资家，因为他们会将其视为懒惰的证据。多花点功夫去获得个人推荐。正如一位风险投资家所说：我并不难找。

paragraphs.original: I know a lot of people. If you can't find some way to reach me, how are you going to create a successful company? One of the most difficult problems for startup founders is deciding when to approach VCs.
paragraphs.translated: 我认识很多人。如果你找不到方法联系到我，你怎么能创建一个成功的企业？对于初创企业的创始人来说，最难的问题之一就是决定何时接触风险投资家。

paragraphs.original: You really only get one chance, because they rely heavily on first impressions. And you can't approach some and save others for later, because (a) they ask who else you've talked to and when and (b) they talk among themselves.
paragraphs.translated: 你真的只有一次机会，因为他们非常重视第一印象。你不能先接触一些人而把其他人留到后来，因为（a）他们会问你还和其他人谈过话以及谈话的时间，（b）他们之间也会相互交流。

paragraphs.original: If you're talking to one VC and he finds out that you were rejected by another several months ago, you'll definitely seem shopworn.So when do you approach VCs? When you can convince them. If the founders have impressive resumes and the idea isn't hard to understand, you could approach VCs quite early.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你和一位风险投资人交谈，而他发现几个月前你曾被另一位投资人拒绝，你肯定会显得过时。那么，你应该在什么时候接触风险投资人呢？当你能够说服他们的时候。如果创始人有令人印象深刻的履历，且想法不难理解，你就可以很早就去接触风险投资人。

paragraphs.original: Whereas if the founders are unknown and the idea is very novel, you might have to launch the thing and show that users loved it before VCs would be convinced.If several VCs are interested in you, they will sometimes be willing to split the deal between them.
paragraphs.translated: 如果创始人不为人知，而想法非常新颖，你可能需要先推出产品，展示用户对它的喜爱，才能说服风险投资家。如果有几家风险投资公司对你感兴趣，他们有时愿意共同分担这笔投资。

paragraphs.original: They're more likely to do this if they're close in the VC pecking order. Such deals may be a net win for founders, because you get multiple VCs interested in your success, and you can ask each for advice about the other.
paragraphs.translated: 如果他们在风险投资的层级中地位相近，这种情况更可能发生。这类交易对于创始人来说可能是净胜，因为你可以让多个风险投资者对你的成功感兴趣，并且可以向每个人咨询关于其他人的意见。

paragraphs.original: One founder I know wrote: Two-firm deals are great. It costs you a little more equity, but being able to play the two firms off each other (as well as ask one if the other is being out of line) is invaluable.
paragraphs.translated: 一位创始人曾写道：与两家公司达成协议很棒。这会让你多付出一些股权，但能够在这两家公司之间进行博弈（以及向一家公司询问另一家是否在不合理行事）是非常宝贵的。

paragraphs.original: When you do negotiate with VCs, remember that they've done this a lot more than you have. They've invested in dozens of startups, whereas this is probably the first you've founded. But don't let them or the situation intimidate you.
paragraphs.translated: 当你与风险投资人谈判时，记住他们在这方面有着比你更丰富的经验。他们已经投资了数十家初创公司，而这可能是你第一次创办公司。但不要让他们或这种情况吓倒你。

paragraphs.original: The average founder is smarter than the average VC. So just do what you'd do in any complex, unfamiliar situation: proceed deliberately, and question anything that seems odd.It is, unfortunately, common for VCs to put terms in an agreement whose consequences surprise founders later, and also common for VCs to defend things they do by saying that they're standard in the industry.
paragraphs.translated: 平均而言，创始人比风险投资家更聪明。因此，在面对复杂且不熟悉的情况时，只需谨慎行事，并对任何看起来奇怪的事情提出质疑。不幸的是，风险投资家在协议中加入一些条款，其后果往往会在日后让创始人感到意外，而风险投资家也常常通过声称这些做法在行业内是标准的来为自己辩护。

paragraphs.original: Standard, schmandard; the whole industry is only a few decades old, and rapidly evolving. The concept of "standard" is a useful one when you're operating on a small scale (Y Combinator uses identical terms for every deal because for tiny seed-stage investments it's not worth the overhead of negotiating individual deals), but it doesn't apply at the VC level.
paragraphs.translated: 标准，什么标准；整个行业只有几十年的历史，而且正在迅速发展。当规模较小时，“标准”这个概念是有用的（Y Combinator 对每一笔交易都使用相同的条款，因为对于小型种子阶段的投资来说，单独谈判每笔交易的成本不划算），但在风险投资层面，这并不适用。

paragraphs.original: On that scale, every negotiation is unique.Most successful startups get money from more than one of the preceding five sources. [6] And, confusingly, the names of funding sources also tend to be used as the names of different rounds.
paragraphs.translated: 在这个层面上，每一场谈判都是独特的。大多数成功的初创公司都会从上述五个来源中的多个获得资金。[6] 而且，令人困惑的是，资金来源的名称通常也用作不同轮融资的名称。

paragraphs.original: The best way to explain how it all works is to follow the case of a hypothetical startup.Stage 1: Seed RoundOur startup begins when a group of three friends have an idea-- either an idea for something they might build, or simply the idea "let's start a company." Presumably they already have some source of food and shelter.
paragraphs.translated: 最好的解释方式是通过一个假设的初创公司的案例来说明。第一阶段：种子轮融资。我们的初创公司始于三个朋友有了一个想法——这个想法可能是他们想要构建的某个东西，或者仅仅是“让我们成立一家公司”的想法。假设他们已经有了一定的生活来源和住宿条件。

paragraphs.original: But if you have food and shelter, you probably also have something you're supposed to be working on: either classwork, or a job. So if you want to work full-time on a startup, your money situation will probably change too.A lot of startup founders say they started the company without any idea of what they planned to do.
paragraphs.translated: 但如果你有食物和住处，你可能也有一些应该去做的事情：要么是学业，要么是工作。所以，如果你想全职投入创业，你的经济状况可能会有所变化。许多创业者的创始人说，他们创立公司时根本不知道自己打算做什么。

paragraphs.original: This is actually less common than it seems: many have to claim they thought of the idea after quitting because otherwise their former employer would own it.The three friends decide to take the leap. Since most startups are in competitive businesses, you not only want to work full-time on them, but more than full-time.
paragraphs.translated: 这实际上比看起来要少见：很多人不得不声称自己是在离职后才想到这个点子的，否则他们的前雇主就会拥有这个点子。三个朋友决定冒险一试。由于大多数初创公司都处于竞争激烈的行业，你不仅需要全职投入，还需要投入更多的时间。

paragraphs.original: So some or all of the friends quit their jobs or leave school. (Some of the founders in a startup can stay in grad school, but at least one has to make the company his full-time job.)They're going to run the company out of one of their apartments at first, and since they don't have any users they don't have to pay much for infrastructure.
paragraphs.translated: 所以有些或所有的朋友辞掉了工作或离开了学校。（创业公司的创始人中有些人可以继续读研究生，但至少有一个人必须把公司作为全职工作。）他们一开始会在其中一个人的公寓里运营公司，由于还没有用户，他们不需要在基础设施上投入太多资金。

paragraphs.original: Their main expenses are setting up the company, which costs a couple thousand dollars in legal work and registration fees, and the living expenses of the founders.The phrase "seed investment" covers a broad range.
paragraphs.translated: 他们的主要支出包括设立公司的费用，这在法律工作和注册费用上需要几千美元，以及创始人的生活费用。“种子投资”这个术语涵盖的范围很广。

paragraphs.original: To some VC firms it means $500,000, but to most startups it means several months' living expenses. We'll suppose our group of friends start with $15,000 from their friend's rich uncle, who they give 5% of the company in return.
paragraphs.translated: 对一些风投公司来说，这意味着50万美元，但对大多数初创公司而言，这意味着几个月的生活费用。假设我们这群朋友从他们富有的叔叔那里得到了15,000美元，作为交换，他们给了叔叔公司5%的股份。

paragraphs.original: There's only common stock at this stage. They leave 20% as an options pool for later employees (but they set things up so that they can issue this stock to themselves if they get bought early and most is still unissued), and the three founders each get 25%.By living really cheaply they think they can make the remaining money last five months.
paragraphs.translated: 目前只有普通股。他们留出20%作为期权池，供未来的员工使用（但同时他们也安排好了，如果公司提前被收购且大部分股票尚未发放，他们可以将这些股票分配给自己），三位创始人各自获得25%的股份。通过极其节俭的生活，他们认为剩余的资金可以维持五个月。

paragraphs.original: When you have five months' runway left, how soon do you need to start looking for your next round? Answer: immediately. It takes time to find investors, and time (always more than you expect) for the deal to close even after they say yes.
paragraphs.translated: 当你只剩下五个月的资金时，你需要多快开始寻找下一轮融资？答案：立即开始。寻找投资者需要时间，即使他们答应投资，交易完成也需要时间（通常比你预期的要长）。

paragraphs.original: So if our group of founders know what they're doing they'll start sniffing around for angel investors right away. But of course their main job is to build version 1 of their software.The friends might have liked to have more money in this first phase, but being slightly underfunded teaches them an important lesson.
paragraphs.translated: 所以，如果我们的创始人团队知道自己在做什么，他们就会立刻开始寻找天使投资者。但当然，他们的主要任务是开发软件的1.0版本。朋友们可能希望在这一阶段能有更多的资金，但资金稍微不足会教会他们一个重要的教训。

paragraphs.original: For a startup, cheapness is power. The lower your costs, the more options you have—not just at this stage, but at every point till you're profitable. When you have a high "burn rate," you're always under time pressure, which means (a) you don't have time for your ideas to evolve, and (b) you're often forced to take deals you don't like.Every startup's rule should be: spend little, and work fast.After ten weeks' work the three friends have built a prototype that gives one a taste of what their product will do.
paragraphs.translated: 对于一家创业公司，成本低廉就是力量。你的成本越低，你拥有的选择就越多——不仅在当前阶段，而且在直到盈利的每一个节点都是如此。当你的“烧钱率”很高时，你总是处于时间压力之下，这意味着（a）你没有时间让想法逐渐成熟，（b）你经常被迫接受不喜欢的交易。每家创业公司的规则应该是：少花钱，快速行动。经过十周的努力，三位朋友已经开发出一个原型，让人们初步领略到他们的产品将能实现的功能。

paragraphs.original: It's not what they originally set out to do—in the process of writing it, they had some new ideas. And it only does a fraction of what the finished product will do, but that fraction includes stuff that no one else has done before.They've also written at least a skeleton business plan, addressing the five fundamental questions: what they're going to do, why users need it, how large the market is, how they'll make money, and who the competitors are and why this company is going to beat them.
paragraphs.translated: 这并不是他们最初打算做的事情——在写作过程中，他们产生了一些新想法。它目前只能完成最终产品的一小部分功能，但这一小部分功能是其他人都未曾实现过的。他们还至少草拟了一个商业计划大纲，回答了五个基本问题：他们打算做什么，用户为什么需要它，市场规模有多大，他们将如何盈利，以及竞争对手是谁，为什么这家公司能够击败他们。

paragraphs.original: (That last has to be more specific than "they suck" or "we'll work really hard.")If you have to choose between spending time on the demo or the business plan, spend most on the demo. Software is not only more convincing, but a better way to explore ideas.Stage 2: Angel RoundWhile writing the prototype, the group has been traversing their network of friends in search of angel investors.
paragraphs.translated: （最后一项必须比“他们很糟糕”或“我们会非常努力”更为具体。）如果你必须在演示和商业计划之间选择投入时间，那么大部分时间应该花在演示上。软件不仅更具说服力，也是探索想法的更好方式。第二阶段：天使轮融资在编写原型的同时，团队一直在通过他们的朋友圈网络寻找天使投资人。

paragraphs.original: They find some just as the prototype is demoable. When they demo it, one of the angels is willing to invest. Now the group is looking for more money: they want enough to last for a year, and maybe to hire a couple friends.
paragraphs.translated: 他们刚刚在原型可以展示的时候找到了一些投资人。在演示时，其中一位天使投资人表示愿意投资。现在团队正在寻找更多的资金：他们希望获得足够的资金以维持一年的运营，或许还能雇佣几位朋友。

paragraphs.original: So they're going to raise $200,000.The angel agrees to invest at a pre-money valuation of $1 million. The company issues $200,000 worth of new shares to the angel; if there were 1000 shares before the deal, this means 200 additional shares.
paragraphs.translated: 他们将筹集20万美元。天使投资人同意以100万美元的投前估值进行投资。公司向天使投资人发行价值20万美元的新股；如果交易前有1000股，这意味着将增发200股。

paragraphs.original: The angel now owns 200/1200 shares, or a sixth of the company, and all the previous shareholders' percentage ownership is diluted by a sixth. After the deal, the capitalization table looks like this: shareholder shares percent ------------------------------- angel 200 16.7 uncle 50 4.2 each founder 250 20.8 option pool 200 16.7 ---- ----- total 1200 100 To keep things simple, I had the angel do a straight cash for stock deal.
paragraphs.translated: [翻译失败] The angel now owns 200/1200 shares, or a sixth of ...

paragraphs.original: In reality the angel might be more likely to make the investment in the form of a convertible loan. A convertible loan is a loan that can be converted into stock later; it works out the same as a stock purchase in the end, but gives the angel more protection against being squashed by VCs in future rounds.Who pays the legal bills for this deal?
paragraphs.translated: 实际上，天使投资者更可能以可转换贷款的形式进行投资。可转换贷款是一种可以在将来转换为股票的贷款；最终的效果与直接购买股票相同，但可以为天使投资者提供更多的保护，防止在未来的融资轮次中被风险投资家挤压。这笔交易的法律费用由谁支付？

paragraphs.original: The startup, remember, only has a couple thousand left. In practice this turns out to be a sticky problem that usually gets solved in some improvised way. Maybe the startup can find lawyers who will do it cheaply in the hope of future work if the startup succeeds.
paragraphs.translated: 这家初创公司记得，只剩下几千美元了。实际上，这往往成为一个棘手的问题，通常需要以某种临时的方式来解决。也许这家初创公司可以找到愿意低价提供服务的律师，寄希望于如果公司成功了，将来还能有更多业务。

paragraphs.original: Maybe someone has a lawyer friend. Maybe the angel pays for his lawyer to represent both sides. (Make sure if you take the latter route that the lawyer is representing you rather than merely advising you, or his only duty is to the investor.)An angel investing $200k would probably expect a seat on the board of directors.
paragraphs.translated: 也许有人有一个律师朋友。也许天使投资者会为律师支付费用，让律师代表双方。（如果你选择后一种方式，一定要确保律师是在代表你，而不仅仅是提供咨询，或者他的唯一职责是对投资者负责。）投资20万美元的天使投资者可能希望获得董事会的一个席位。

paragraphs.original: He might also want preferred stock, meaning a special class of stock that has some additional rights over the common stock everyone else has. Typically these rights include vetoes over major strategic decisions, protection against being diluted in future rounds, and the right to get one's investment back first if the company is sold.Some investors might expect the founders to accept vesting for a sum this size, and others wouldn't.
paragraphs.translated: 他可能还希望获得优先股，这意味着一种具有比普通股股东更多的特殊权利的股票。这些权利通常包括对重大战略决策的否决权、在后续融资轮次中避免股份被稀释的保护，以及在公司出售时优先收回投资的权利。对于这样规模的投资，有些投资者可能希望创始人接受期权授予，而另一些投资者则不会提出这样的要求。

paragraphs.original: VCs are more likely to require vesting than angels. At Viaweb we managed to raise $2.5 million from angels without ever accepting vesting, largely because we were so inexperienced that we were appalled at the idea.
paragraphs.translated: 风险投资家比天使投资人更可能要求股权分期兑现。在Viaweb，我们设法从天使投资人那里筹集了250万美元，而从未接受过分期兑现，主要是因为我们太缺乏经验，对这个想法感到震惊。

paragraphs.original: In practice this turned out to be good, because it made us harder to push around.Our experience was unusual; vesting is the norm for amounts that size. Y Combinator doesn't require vesting, because (a) we invest such small amounts, and (b) we think it's unnecessary, and that the hope of getting rich is enough motivation to keep founders at work.
paragraphs.translated: 实际上，这证明是件好事，因为它让我们更难被左右。我们的经历是非同寻常的；对于这么大数额的投资，分期授予权是常态。Y Combinator 不要求分期授予权，因为（a）我们投资的金额很小，（b）我们认为这没有必要，而且对致富的期望已经足以激励创始人努力工作。

paragraphs.original: But maybe if we were investing millions we would think differently.I should add that vesting is also a way for founders to protect themselves against one another. It solves the problem of what to do if one of the founders quits.
paragraphs.translated: 但也许如果我们投资的是数百万，我们的想法就会不同。我还要补充一点，股权分期授予也是创始人之间相互保护的一种方式。它解决了如果其中一个创始人离职该怎么办的问题。

paragraphs.original: So some founders impose it on themselves when they start the company.The angel deal takes two weeks to close, so we are now three months into the life of the company.The point after you get the first big chunk of angel money will usually be the happiest phase in a startup's life.
paragraphs.translated: 所以一些创始人在创立公司时就自己施加了这种压力。天使轮融资需要两周时间才能完成，所以我们现在已经是公司成立三个月了。在获得第一笔大额天使资金之后，通常会是初创公司生命中最幸福的阶段。

paragraphs.original: It's a lot like being a postdoc: you have no immediate financial worries, and few responsibilities. You get to work on juicy kinds of work, like designing software. You don't have to spend time on bureaucratic stuff, because you haven't hired any bureaucrats yet.
paragraphs.translated: 这很像做博士后：你没有 immediate 的财务担忧，也没有多少责任。你可以从事一些很有意思的工作，比如设计软件。你不必花时间在官僚事务上，因为你还没有雇用任何官僚。

paragraphs.original: Enjoy it while it lasts, and get as much done as you can, because you will never again be so productive.With an apparently inexhaustible sum of money sitting safely in the bank, the founders happily set to work turning their prototype into something they can release.
paragraphs.translated: 趁着还能享受的时候尽情享受吧，并尽可能多地完成工作，因为你再也不会像现在这样高产了。带着银行里安全存放的看似无穷无尽的资金，创始人们愉快地开始将他们的原型产品转化为可以发布的产品。

paragraphs.original: They hire one of their friends—at first just as a consultant, so they can try him out—and then a month later as employee #1. They pay him the smallest salary he can live on, plus 3% of the company in restricted stock, vesting over four years.
paragraphs.translated: 他们聘请了一位朋友，最初只是作为顾问，以便试用他，然后一个月后作为员工#1。他们支付给他能够维持生活的最低工资，外加公司3%的限制性股票，分四年归属。

paragraphs.original: (So after this the option pool is down to 13.7%). [7] They also spend a little money on a freelance graphic designer.How much stock do you give early employees? That varies so much that there's no conventional number.
paragraphs.translated: （因此，期权池减少到13.7%。）[7] 他们还花了一些钱请了一位自由职业的平面设计师。你给早期员工多少股票？这个数字变化很大，所以没有一个常规的数字。

paragraphs.original: If you get someone really good, really early, it might be wise to give him as much stock as the founders. The one universal rule is that the amount of stock an employee gets decreases polynomially with the age of the company.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你很早就找到了一个非常优秀的人，给他和创始人一样多的股份可能是个明智的选择。一条普遍的规则是，员工获得的股份数量会随着公司年龄的增长而呈多项式减少。

paragraphs.original: In other words, you get rich as a power of how early you were. So if some friends want you to come work for their startup, don't wait several months before deciding.A month later, at the end of month four, our group of founders have something they can launch.
paragraphs.translated: 换句话说，你越早加入，就越容易变得富有。所以，如果有些朋友希望你为他们的初创公司工作，不要等上几个月才做决定。一个月后，也就是在第四个月末，我们这群创始人已经有一些可以推出的东西了。

paragraphs.original: Gradually through word of mouth they start to get users. Seeing the system in use by real users—people they don't know—gives them lots of new ideas. Also they find they now worry obsessively about the status of their server.
paragraphs.translated: 渐渐地，通过口碑，他们开始吸引用户。看到系统被真实用户——他们不认识的人——使用，给了他们许多新的想法。同时，他们发现自己现在对服务器的状态变得异常担忧。

paragraphs.original: (How relaxing founders' lives must have been when startups wrote VisiCalc.)By the end of month six, the system is starting to have a solid core of features, and a small but devoted following. People start to write about it, and the founders are starting to feel like experts in their field.We'll assume that their startup is one that could put millions more to use.
paragraphs.translated: （当创业公司编写VisiCalc时，创始人们的生活一定很轻松。）到第六个月末，系统开始具备扎实的核心功能，并拥有了一批虽小却忠实的追随者。人们开始撰写关于它的文章，创始人们也开始感觉自己成为了该领域的专家。我们假设他们的创业公司是那种能够让更多人受益的公司。

paragraphs.original: Perhaps they need to spend a lot on marketing, or build some kind of expensive infrastructure, or hire highly paid salesmen. So they decide to start talking to VCs. They get introductions to VCs from various sources: their angel investor connects them with a couple; they meet a few at conferences; a couple VCs call them after reading about them.Step 3: Series A RoundArmed with their now somewhat fleshed-out business plan and able to demo a real, working system, the founders visit the VCs they have introductions to.
paragraphs.translated:
也许他们需要在营销上投入大量资金，或者建设某种昂贵的基础设施，或者雇佣高薪的销售人员。因此，他们决定开始与风险投资家（VCs）接触。他们从各种来源获得了与风险投资家的引荐：他们的天使投资人帮他们联系了几个；他们在会议上遇到了一些；还有一些风险投资家在读到有关他们的报道后主动联系了他们。

第三步：A轮融资

带着现在更加完善的商业计划，并且能够展示一个真实、运行中的系统，创始人们拜访了那些有引荐关系的风险投资家。

paragraphs.original: They find the VCs intimidating and inscrutable. They all ask the same question: who else have you pitched to? (VCs are like high school girls: they're acutely aware of their position in the VC pecking order, and their interest in a company is a function of the interest other VCs show in it.)One of the VC firms says they want to invest and offers the founders a term sheet.
paragraphs.translated: 他们觉得风险投资家既令人望而生畏又难以捉摸。所有人都问同样的问题：你还向谁推介过？（风险投资家就像高中的女生：她们非常清楚自己在风险投资界的等级地位，对一家公司的兴趣很大程度上取决于其他风险投资家对这家公司的兴趣。）有一家风险投资公司表示想要投资，并向创始人提供了一份条款清单。

paragraphs.original: A term sheet is a summary of what the deal terms will be when and if they do a deal; lawyers will fill in the details later. By accepting the term sheet, the startup agrees to turn away other VCs for some set amount of time while this firm does the "due diligence" required for the deal.
paragraphs.translated: 条款清单是交易条款的概要，当双方决定进行交易时，这些条款将适用；律师将在后续填写详细内容。通过接受条款清单，创业公司同意在一定时间内拒绝其他风险投资人的邀约，以便该投资方进行交易所需的“尽职调查”。

paragraphs.original: Due diligence is the corporate equivalent of a background check: the purpose is to uncover any hidden bombs that might sink the company later, like serious design flaws in the product, pending lawsuits against the company, intellectual property issues, and so on.
paragraphs.translated: 尽职调查相当于企业的背景调查：其目的是发现可能日后拖垮公司的任何隐患，比如产品存在严重的设计缺陷、针对公司的未决诉讼、知识产权问题等。

paragraphs.original: VCs' legal and financial due diligence is pretty thorough, but the technical due diligence is generally a joke. [8]The due diligence discloses no ticking bombs, and six weeks later they go ahead with the deal.
paragraphs.translated: 风险投资人的法律和财务尽职调查相当彻底，但技术尽职调查通常流于形式。尽职调查未发现任何潜在的重大问题，六周后他们继续推进交易。

paragraphs.original: Here are the terms: a $2 million investment at a pre-money valuation of $4 million, meaning that after the deal closes the VCs will own a third of the company (2 / (4 + 2)). The VCs also insist that prior to the deal the option pool be enlarged by an additional hundred shares.
paragraphs.translated: 以下是条款：以400万美元的投前估值进行200万美元的投资，这意味着交易完成后，风险投资方将拥有公司三分之一的股份（2 / (4 + 2)）。风险投资方还要求在交易前将期权池增加100股。

paragraphs.original: So the total number of new shares issued is 750, and the cap table becomes: shareholder shares percent ------------------------------- VCs 650 33.3 angel 200 10.3 uncle 50 2.6 each founder 250 12.8 employee 36* 1.8 *unvested option pool 264 13.5 ---- ----- total 1950 100 This picture is unrealistic in several respects.
paragraphs.translated:
所以发行的新股总数为750股，股本结构变为：
股东 股份数 持股比例
--------------------
VCs 650 33.3%
天使投资人 200 10.3%
叔叔 50 2.6%
每位创始人 250 12.8%
员工 36 1.8%
*未归属的期权池 264 13.5%
---- -----
总计 1950 100

这个结构在多个方面是不现实的。

paragraphs.original: For example, while the percentages might end up looking like this, it's unlikely that the VCs would keep the existing numbers of shares. In fact, every bit of the startup's paperwork would probably be replaced, as if the company were being founded anew.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，虽然最终的百分比可能看起来是这样的，但风险投资方不太可能保留现有的股份数量。实际上，初创公司的所有文件可能会被全部替换，就像公司重新成立一样。

paragraphs.original: Also, the money might come in several tranches, the later ones subject to various conditions—though this is apparently more common in deals with lower-tier VCs (whose lot in life is to fund more dubious startups) than with the top firms.And of course any VCs reading this are probably rolling on the floor laughing at how my hypothetical VCs let the angel keep his 10.3 of the company.
paragraphs.translated: 此外，资金可能会分几批到账，后期的资金则取决于各种条件——尽管这种情况显然在与较低层级的风险投资公司（他们的命运是为更不可靠的初创公司提供资金）的交易中更为常见，而在顶级投资机构中则较少见。当然，任何正在阅读此文章的风险投资家可能都会笑得前仰后合，因为我的假设中的风险投资家竟然让天使投资者保留了公司10.3%的股份。

paragraphs.original: I admit, this is the Bambi version; in simplifying the picture, I've also made everyone nicer. In the real world, VCs regard angels the way a jealous husband feels about his wife's previous boyfriends.
paragraphs.translated: 我承认，这是简化版的故事；在简化过程中，我也让大家看起来更加和善。在现实世界中，风险投资家看待天使投资者的态度就像一个嫉妒的丈夫对待妻子的前男友一样。

paragraphs.original: To them the company didn't exist before they invested in it. [9]I don't want to give the impression you have to do an angel round before going to VCs. In this example I stretched things out to show multiple sources of funding in action.
paragraphs.translated: 在他们投资之前，这家公司对他们来说并不存在。[9]我不想给人留下必须先进行天使轮融资才能去找风险投资的印象。在这个例子中，我拉长了过程，是为了展示多种融资来源的实际运作。

paragraphs.original: Some startups could go directly from seed funding to a VC round; several of the companies we've funded have.The founders are required to vest their shares over four years, and the board is now reconstituted to consist of two VCs, two founders, and a fifth person acceptable to both.
paragraphs.translated: 一些初创公司可以直接从种子轮融资跳到风险投资轮；我们资助的几家公司就是这样做的。创始人需要在四年内逐步兑现他们的股份，董事会现在重组为两名风险投资人、两名创始人和一名双方都认可的第五人员。

paragraphs.original: The angel investor cheerfully surrenders his board seat.At this point there is nothing new our startup can teach us about funding—or at least, nothing good. [10] The startup will almost certainly hire more people at this point; those millions must be put to work, after all.
paragraphs.translated: 天使投资人愉快地放弃了他在董事会的席位。此时，我们的初创公司已经没有什么新的东西可以教我们关于融资的事了——至少没有什么好的东西。[10] 初创公司几乎肯定会在这个时候雇用更多的人；毕竟，那些数百万的资金必须派上用场。

paragraphs.original: The company may do additional funding rounds, presumably at higher valuations. They may if they are extraordinarily fortunate do an IPO, which we should remember is also in principle a round of funding, regardless of its de facto purpose.
paragraphs.translated: 该公司可能会进行额外的融资轮次，预计估值会更高。如果他们极其幸运，甚至可能进行首次公开募股（IPO），我们应该记得，无论其实际目的如何，IPO原则上也是一轮融资。

paragraphs.original: But that, if not beyond the bounds of possibility, is beyond the scope of this article.Deals Fall ThroughAnyone who's been through a startup will find the preceding portrait to be missing something: disasters.
paragraphs.translated: 但即便这并非完全不可能，也超出了本文的讨论范围。交易失败在所难免。任何经历过创业的人都会发现前面的描述缺少了点什么：灾难。

paragraphs.original: If there's one thing all startups have in common, it's that something is always going wrong. And nowhere more than in matters of funding.For example, our hypothetical startup never spent more than half of one round before securing the next.
paragraphs.translated: 如果有一件事是所有初创公司共有的，那就是总有些事情会出问题。而在资金问题上，这种情况尤为突出。例如，我们假设的这家初创公司在获得下一轮融资之前，从未花掉上一轮融资的一半以上。

paragraphs.original: That's more ideal than typical. Many startups—even successful ones—come close to running out of money at some point. Terrible things happen to startups when they run out of money, because they're designed for growth, not adversity.But the most unrealistic thing about the series of deals I've described is that they all closed.
paragraphs.translated: 这比典型情况要理想得多。许多初创企业——即使成功的也不例外——在某个时刻都会接近资金枯竭。当初创企业资金耗尽时，糟糕的事情就会发生，因为它们是为增长而设计的，而不是为了应对逆境。但我在描述的这一系列交易中最不切实际的一点是，它们全部都成功完成了。

paragraphs.original: In the startup world, closing is not what deals do. What deals do is fall through. If you're starting a startup you would do well to remember that. Birds fly; fish swim; deals fall through.Why? Partly the reason deals seem to fall through so often is that you lie to yourself.
paragraphs.translated: 在创业世界里，成交并不是交易的常态。交易常常会落空。如果你正在创办一家创业公司，最好记住这一点。鸟儿会飞，鱼儿会游，交易则常常会落空。为什么？部分原因是交易似乎经常落空，是因为你对自己撒了谎。

paragraphs.original: You want the deal to close, so you start to believe it will. But even correcting for this, startup deals fall through alarmingly often—far more often than, say, deals to buy real estate. The reason is that it's such a risky environment.
paragraphs.translated: 你希望这笔交易能够达成，因此开始相信它会成功。但即使考虑到这一点，初创公司的交易失败率依然高得惊人——远高于购买房地产的交易。原因是这种环境风险极高。

paragraphs.original: People about to fund or acquire a startup are prone to wicked cases of buyer's remorse. They don't really grasp the risk they're taking till the deal's about to close. And then they panic. And not just inexperienced angel investors, but big companies too.So if you're a startup founder wondering why some angel investor isn't returning your phone calls, you can at least take comfort in the thought that the same thing is happening to other deals a hundred times the size.The example of a startup's history that I've presented is like a skeleton—accurate so far as it goes, but needing to be fleshed out to be a complete picture.
paragraphs.translated: 即将投资或收购初创企业的人都容易患上严重的买方懊悔。他们直到交易即将完成时，才真正意识到自己所承担的风险。然后他们开始恐慌。不仅仅是缺乏经验的天使投资者会这样，大公司也是如此。所以，如果你是一位初创企业的创始人，正在纳闷为什么某个天使投资者不回你的电话，你至少可以安慰自己，同样的事情也在其他规模大百倍的交易中发生。我所呈现的初创企业历史示例就像一副骨架——在它所涉及的范围内是准确的，但需要充实才能成为一幅完整的画面。

paragraphs.original: To get a complete picture, just add in every possible disaster.A frightening prospect? In a way. And yet also in a way encouraging. The very uncertainty of startups frightens away almost everyone. People overvalue stability—especially young people, who ironically need it least.
paragraphs.translated: 为了得到一个完整的画面，只需把所有可能的灾难都加进去。这听起来令人恐惧？在某种程度上确实如此。然而，在某种程度上这也令人鼓舞。初创企业的不确定性几乎吓跑了所有人。人们过于看重稳定性——尤其是年轻人，讽刺的是，他们最不需要这种稳定性。

paragraphs.original: And so in starting a startup, as in any really bold undertaking, merely deciding to do it gets you halfway there. On the day of the race, most of the other runners won't show up. Notes[1] The aim of such regulations is to protect widows and orphans from crooked investment schemes; people with a million dollars in liquid assets are assumed to be able to protect themselves.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，无论是创办一家初创公司还是进行任何大胆的尝试，决定去做这件事就已经完成了一大半。在比赛当天，大多数其他选手根本不会出现。注[1] 这类法规的目的是保护寡妇和孤儿免受欺诈性投资计划的侵害；而拥有百万美元流动资产的人则被认为有能力保护自己。

paragraphs.original: The unintended consequence is that the investments that generate the highest returns, like hedge funds, are available only to the rich.[2] Consulting is where product companies go to die. IBM is the most famous example.
paragraphs.translated: 意想不到的后果是，那些回报最高的投资，比如对冲基金，只有富人才能享有。[2] 咨询业是产品公司走向衰亡的地方。IBM是最著名的例子。

paragraphs.original: So starting as a consulting company is like starting out in the grave and trying to work your way up into the world of the living.[3] If "near you" doesn't mean the Bay Area, Boston, or Seattle, consider moving.
paragraphs.translated: 所以，从一家咨询公司开始，就像是从坟墓里开始，试图努力进入活人的世界。[3] 如果“靠近你”并不意味着旧金山湾区、波士顿或西雅图，那么请考虑搬家。

paragraphs.original: It's not a coincidence you haven't heard of many startups from Philadelphia.[4] Investors are often compared to sheep. And they are like sheep, but that's a rational response to their situation. Sheep act the way they do for a reason.
paragraphs.translated: 你没听说过很多来自费城的初创公司，这并非偶然。[4] 投资人经常被比作羊群。而他们确实像羊群，但这对他们所处的环境来说是一种理性的反应。羊群之所以如此行事，自有其道理。

paragraphs.original: If all the other sheep head for a certain field, it's probably good grazing. And when a wolf appears, is he going to eat a sheep in the middle of the flock, or one near the edge?[5] This was partly confidence, and partly simple ignorance.
paragraphs.translated: 如果所有的羊都朝某个牧场走去，那里的草很可能很好。当狼出现时，它是会吃掉羊群中间的羊，还是靠近边缘的羊呢？这既是部分自信，也是部分简单的无知。

paragraphs.original: We didn't know ourselves which VC firms were the impressive ones. We thought software was all that mattered. But that turned out to be the right direction to be naive in: it's much better to overestimate than underestimate the importance of making a good product.[6] I've omitted one source: government grants.
paragraphs.translated: 我们自己也不知道哪些风投公司是真正令人印象深刻的。我们认为软件才是关键。但事实证明，这种无知的方向是对的：高估而不是低估制作优质产品的重要性要好得多。[6] 我还忽略了一个来源：政府补助。

paragraphs.original: I don't think these are even worth thinking about for the average startup. Governments may mean well when they set up grant programs to encourage startups, but what they give with one hand they take away with the other: the process of applying is inevitably so arduous, and the restrictions on what you can do with the money so burdensome, that it would be easier to take a job to get the money.
paragraphs.translated: 我认为这些对于普通初创公司来说根本不值得考虑。政府在设立资助项目以鼓励初创公司时可能是出于好意，但往往是一手给予，一手又拿走：申请过程必然极其繁琐，而且对资金使用的限制如此繁重，以至于找份工作赚钱反而更容易。

paragraphs.original: You should be especially suspicious of grants whose purpose is some kind of social engineering-- e.g. to encourage more startups to be started in Mississippi. Free money to start a startup in a place where few succeed is hardly free.Some government agencies run venture funding groups, which make investments rather than giving grants.
paragraphs.translated: 你应该特别警惕那些旨在进行某种社会工程的资助，比如鼓励在密西西比州创办更多的初创企业。在一个很少有人成功的地区创办企业而获得的“免费”资金，实际上并不那么自由。一些政府机构运营着风险投资部门，它们进行投资而不是提供资助。

paragraphs.original: For example, the CIA runs a venture fund called In-Q-Tel that is modelled on private sector funds and apparently generates good returns. They would probably be worth approaching—if you don't mind taking money from the CIA.[7] Options have largely been replaced with restricted stock, which amounts to the same thing.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，中央情报局（CIA）运营着一个名为In-Q-Tel的风险基金，该基金模仿私营部门的基金模式，据说能产生良好的回报。如果你不介意从中央情报局那里接受资金，可以考虑与他们接触。[7] 期权在很大程度上已被限制性股票所取代，这实际上是一回事。

paragraphs.original: Instead of earning the right to buy stock, the employee gets the stock up front, and earns the right not to have to give it back. The shares set aside for this purpose are still called the "option pool."[8] First-rate technical people do not generally hire themselves out to do due diligence for VCs.
paragraphs.translated: 员工不是通过赚取购买股票的权利来获得股票，而是直接获得股票，并且通过努力获得不需归还这些股票的权利。为这一目的预留的股票仍然被称为“期权池”。[8] 一流的技術人才通常不會自願為風險投資者進行盡職調查。

paragraphs.original: So the most difficult part for startup founders is often responding politely to the inane questions of the "expert" they send to look you over.[9] VCs regularly wipe out angels by issuing arbitrary amounts of new stock.
paragraphs.translated: 所以，对于初创企业的创始人来说，最困难的部分往往是礼貌地回答那些被派来考察你的“专家”提出的荒谬问题。[9] 风险投资公司经常通过发行任意数量的新股来稀释天使投资者的股份。

paragraphs.original: They seem to have a standard piece of casuistry for this situation: that the angels are no longer working to help the company, and so don't deserve to keep their stock. This of course reflects a willful misunderstanding of what investment means; like any investor, the angel is being compensated for risks he took earlier.
paragraphs.translated: 他们似乎对此情况有一套标准的诡辩：即天使投资者不再为公司工作，因此不配继续持有他们的股份。这当然反映了一种故意的误解，即不了解投资的含义；就像任何投资者一样，天使投资者是为了补偿他之前所承担的风险。

paragraphs.original: By a similar logic, one could argue that the VCs should be deprived of their shares when the company goes public.[10] One new thing the company might encounter is a down round, or a funding round at valuation lower than the previous round.
paragraphs.translated: 按照类似的逻辑，有人可能会认为当公司上市时，风险投资家应该被剥夺他们的股份。[10] 公司可能遇到的一个新情况是降价融资，即以低于前一轮估值的价格进行融资。

paragraphs.original: Down rounds are bad news; it is generally the common stock holders who take the hit. Some of the most fearsome provisions in VC deal terms have to do with down rounds—like "full ratchet anti-dilution," which is as frightening as it sounds.Founders are tempted to ignore these clauses, because they think the company will either be a big success or a complete bust.
paragraphs.translated: 降价融资是坏消息；通常普通股持有人会受到打击。风投条款中最令人恐惧的一些条款与降价融资有关，比如“完全棘轮反稀释”条款，听起来就令人害怕。创始人往往倾向于忽略这些条款，因为他们认为公司要么会大获成功，要么彻底失败。

paragraphs.original: VCs know otherwise: it's not uncommon for startups to have moments of adversity before they ultimately succeed. So it's worth negotiating anti-dilution provisions, even though you don't think you need to, and VCs will try to make you feel that you're being gratuitously troublesome.Thanks to Sam Altman, Hutch Fishman, Steve Huffman, Jessica Livingston, Sesha Pratap, Stan Reiss, Andy Singleton, Zak Stone, and Aaron Swartz for reading drafts of this.Arabic Translation
paragraphs.translated: 风险投资家们清楚：创业公司在最终成功之前，经历逆境的时刻并不罕见。因此，即使你觉得没有必要，也值得就反稀释条款进行谈判，而风险投资家们会试图让你觉得自己是在无端制造麻烦。感谢Sam Altman、Hutch Fishman、Steve Huffman、Jessica Livingston、Sesha Pratap、Stan Reiss、Andy Singleton、Zak Stone和Aaron Swartz审阅本文草稿。阿拉伯语翻译
